sentence.idiomatic: As long as you are willing to put your mind to it, a small business can also make a lot of money.
As soon as he has a question he asks other people. He never figures things out for himself.
Hurry up and think. Help me to think up what the next step I take should be.
His reasoning ability is very strong. He suits doing detective work.
The facts bear out that the police's inference was correct--he is the murderer.

word.literal: to be in the course of

sentence.idiomatic: In the reasoning process, if there is one error in the chain, the conclusion that results will be unreliable.
They say that that movie star got a facelift.
They say that after the Beijing Olympics the real estate prices nationwide will fall.
They say that a Disneyland is going to be built in Shanghai. Is this information reliable?
These past few years talent shows have been really popular.
Because stocks have been soaring lately, stock speculation software has also started to gain popularity in the market.
As a 17-year-old she depended on her first album's huge sales in order to quickly rise in popularity in entertainment circles.
David Beckham is so handsome, he deserves the title of "idol."
She has proven herself worthy as a graduate of the department of Chinese; she writes articles simply superbly.
The service at this hotel is very attentive. It deserves its five stars.
Women won't love a man that's not bad... what kind of logic is that?
I think that the plot of this movie is a bit illogical.
His thesis is lacking logic. It is not persuasive.
His words are full of loopholes; they can't stand up to real scrutiny.
I recommend that you deliberate in a little more detail over this project.
After going through repeated deliberation, he finally decided on a topic for his thesis.
As the saying goes, "To each his own." What you like won't necessarily be what I like.
To each his own. No matter what others say, the most important thing is that it suits you.
To each his own. Every person has things they like. Why do you think you have to be the same as other people?
You're doing sudoku yet again. What exactly is it, anyway? It has you so entranced.

It's a kind of numerical reasoning game that requires mental effort. In a 9 by 9 grid there are 3 by 3 smaller grids called ``blocks." In these squares, you fill in the numbers 1 to 9. Each number can only appear once in each row, each column, and each block. You can't repeat them. That's why it's called ``sudoku" [ ``numerical solitude"].
It's that complicated? I heard the Japanese that invented it.

They say it was a Swiss person that invented the game, but it never attracted any attention. In the 80's a Japanese magazine publisher imported it to Japan, increased the difficulty of the game, and of course gave it a Japanese name: ``sudoku." Later the game got popular in Japan and the United States.
Oh, so that's how it happened. You really deserve the title of sudoku addict, knowing all that so well. So, by the way, what does the game really test? Math? Logic?
Actually, in the sudoku solving process you don't use mathematical calculations at all. It's more logic, and you need to be patient and focused, because you have to carry out test after test.
It's sounds so difficult. I don't think I'll try it.

Just practice it and you're fine. Basic sudoku puzzles provide a lot of numbers, so you only need to figure out a few yourself. As the difficulty increases, the numbers provided become fewer and fewer, requiring you to put more thought into it.

word.literal: to be unable to follow the reasoning

sentence.idiomatic: I'm getting dizzy just listening. How could so many people like such a hassle of a puzzle? I just don't get it.
Hey, to each his own.

word.literal: to put one's mind to something

character.pinyin: luóbo qīngcài, gè yǒu suǒ ài
